The time to be buying is on further dips as earnings season plays out and bad news tanks these names further. I’d be dollar cost averaging through these dips but staying underweight on allocations till later in the year.

I expect to increase allocations as we go further into the year.

A Biden caused democrat rout in the midterm could set the markets up for a run up.

favorite_posts.cooked:
The trick in HML is to have very low overhead, a large % of Cap Table in Equity, and local presence in your physical market. In addition you must have the capability to take over any defaulted project and make more money on the completion of the project than the Company would made if the loan performed.

In a private fund that I am a member of we earn between 12% and 16% annualized depending on cash drag in any one quarter.

I find the comment from that gentleman to be valid for his experience, because he probably has never been on the street really making loans rather than pushing paper.

But I have also been in the business for over 15 years.

Ralph

I did a face palm during the webinar when Nance said in one sentence “already secured limited partner”, but then later on says “within weeks of finalizing” (regarding the CLC limited partner). I’m also glad we finally hashed out what Craig is getting: Webinar 1, $25M for $50M of value. Webinar 2, $25M for $33M of value. Webinar 3, $13M for $15M of value.

Also, not sure if anyone has brought this up. This deal is completely centered around Craig. Craig’s relationships. Craig’s experience. So what if Craig dies? I imagine the answer will be selling parcels of land to recoup cost.

I just wired my investment into the REIT this afternoon. In speaking with Elisa from IR I got some updates that she said I could share.

They just closed on a 188 SFH portfolio in Dallas. She says it was purchased at 30% under the market rate with mostly month to month leases. They have a capital improvement plan over a few years to upgrade the homes but they see plenty of immediate upside in rents and valuation as they bring new tenants in with higher rents.

They are at roughly 1,750 homes today with a plan to buy at least 1,500 more in 2022. Adding 2,000 is their stretch goal. They’ll be looking in existing markets still but also looking at expanding in Savannah, GA and Huntsville, AL.

Also the NAV will adjust next week most likely.

posts.cooked: While not common, fund managers frequently can obtain debt secured only by their limited partnership interests and cash flows generated by underlying investments. Some lenders don’t like these loans because the lenders, if they had to step into the shoes of the manager, are at the mercy of any rights (or lack thereof) the fund manager might have with respect to the partnership. In the case of Dyal and BCP, I suspect CAZ has virtually none. But in cases where there is demonstrated cash flow and the leverage is modest, this type of loan (often called a “B” line) is usually available at floating interest rates at 3-4% over prime. The advantage of this loan arrangement is that the manager can borrow up to the specified max leverage amount (a function of capital committed) or pay it down as desired. So in the case of CAZ, I suspect their loan facility will allow for immediate leverage for those investors that opt to use it. There is frequently an “unused commitment fee” for undrawn amounts that the lender will charge.

posts.cooked: Another reason why I don’t like this deal is, it gives CAZ the power to get into any deal without a buyout from the investors. First there would be huge extra cash sitting because of the leverage money they are going to borrow, second if the performance of the overall fund is above %8, cash will accumulate. Not only we would be diluted by peo1, which is probably halfway of its potential but also by future investments that you have no way of rejecting. Another point is if interests rates go up substantially over the next couple of years, many people might be forced to sell to avoid high interest rates. I think this is a great deal if you have invested in peo1 as well. If not, just liquidity and leverage is not enough for peo2 and but especially peo3 investors.

I’d like to know how the leverage is done. In my opinion, when a bank provides a loan, it would ask for collateral and that can only be the underlying assets. In the extreme market conditions, there must be possibilities of forced liquidations. That scenario can dramatically reduce the values of those leveraged accounts. It can also impact the valuations of non-leveraged accounts and those choosing not to be GPO.

The other concern is that PE market is very hot at this point. If the market cools down and the new money flow slows down or stop, the future 8% distribution can be questioned.

I am in both PEO II and PEO III, I will likely choose to opt out this conversion.

posts.cooked:
Sharing a note on AngelList I received from Phil Nadel at Forefront Venture Partners (affiliated with Barbara Corcoran - although I’m not sure how involved she is). Thought it was worth sharing, given the focus on due diligence. It’s a little pitchy at points, but there are good points in here nonetheless for anyone considering whether to invest on AngelList today.

Hi Andrew,

I was 11 years old when I went skiing for the first time. It was a school trip. I had never taken a ski lesson but didn’t think it looked that difficult. So I rented my skis and followed my friends onto the slopes. Down the slopes I soared, gleeful, until I realized I had a big problem: I didn’t know how to stop. I crashed into barricades at the bottom of the slope and was rushed to the hospital. I still have a scar on my right knee to remind me of this youthful foolishness.

I started helping companies invest in and acquire startups when I was in college. One week after I graduated college, I started my first company–to help SPACs (then called blind pools) acquire target companies. And I have been investing in and advising startups ever since (33+ years).

Just like the skiing accident, I have also been hurt by some of the hundreds of investments I’ve made. I have investment scar tissue. It reminds me every day of the importance of due diligence.

Investing in startups without doing deep due diligence is like skiing down a mountain without having learned the requisite skills. It can feel thrilling, but it’s foolish, it’s dangerous and can often lead to bad outcomes. And scar tissue.

Why am I telling you this? Because I am concerned. Concerned about the startup investing environment, concerned about the lack of due diligence, concerned about the impact of FOMO (fear of missing out) overcoming investors’ good judgment. You are a member of the Forefront Venture Partners syndicate. You are likely also a member of other syndicates on AngelList and perhaps other platforms. I feel it is incumbent on me to alert you to an alarming practice that has cropped up across platforms: syndicates are syndicating deals without doing any due diligence. In fact, many times, the companies are not even aware that the syndicate has syndicated the deal. The companies have never spoken to the syndicate lead and have not authorized them to syndicate the deal. The syndicate gets an allocation from another investor in the deal and decides to syndicate it on AngelList. As a result, they have done zero due diligence. And yet you are relying on syndicate leads – and paying them, in the form of carried interest – not just to source deals, but to perform rigorous due diligence. I fear you may not even be aware of the fact that they are often doing no due diligence at all.

There is a lot of capital in search of startups to invest in — and a rush to deploy it. Investors have FOMO if they miss what seems like a great deal. Startups are able to raise capital without giving investors the opportunity to perform due diligence. This can lead to foolish decisions and harmful outcomes.

Just yesterday, we were at the tail end of our due diligence on a deal we were excited about. But I had a nagging sense that something wasn’t right. So, I kept pushing. The company claimed to have just signed a deal with a major restaurant chain for $20M. I asked them to connect me with the restaurant chain so I could verify this. They said too many investors had already spoken with them and they did not want to request yet another reference call. My nagging sense turned into full-on, red-flag worry. I asked some connections I had at the restaurant chain to investigate for me. They came back and told me they had no deal with the startup. They had one quick call with them and it went no further. We had caught the startup in an outright lie. One that many investors have already fallen victim to. In fact, another group on AngelList syndicated the deal.

Here’s another recent example. One of our portfolio companies raised a follow-on round. Another syndicate syndicated the deal and AngelList later withdrew it because the syndicate misrepresented many of the deal terms and facts about the company. Our portfolio company was unaware of this group, had never spoken with them nor given them the authority to syndicate their deal. And if you had invested with them, you would have done so based on incorrect information. This scenario is playing out weekly on AngelList.

You may be wondering if due diligence really matters, if it really affects your investment returns. The answer is absolutely! According to the largest study of angel investors ever, conducted by the Angel Capital Association and the Kauffman Foundation: “Spending time on due diligence is significantly related to better outcomes. Simply splitting the sample between investors who spent less than the median twenty hours of due diligence and investors who spent more shows an overall multiple difference of 5.9X for those with high due diligence compared to only 1.1X for those with low due diligence. The exits where investors spent more than 40 hours doing due diligence (the top quartile) experienced a 7.1X multiple.”

The importance of due diligence is clear. That’s why our due diligence process is so rigorous. And yet we are seeing more and more syndicate leads sharing deals where they have no relationship with the companies. (Some syndicates rely on lead investors to conduct due diligence, but large firms often do only cursory due diligence on early-stage deals where they are investing small amounts in order to have the option to invest in the winners at a later stage. And you have no transparency into their level of due diligence and no opportunity to ask questions). These syndicates have not done even the most basic due diligence. They do not give you access to the founders in an exclusive webinar, as we always do, so you can meet the team and ask them questions before making your investment decision. They do not secure pro-rata rights, like we always do, so you have the opportunity to invest in future rounds. And they certainly do not have a written guarantee to receive regular investor updates from the company, as we always do, so you can keep up to date on the company’s progress. And they don’t do anything to help their portfolio companies succeed after investing, like we always do. How could they do any of these things? They have literally never even spoken to the companies.

Where does that leave us? We clearly have a problem, but what can we do about it? At a very minimum, I propose that AngelList should require all syndicate leads to have a signed statement from the startup specifically giving the syndicate permission to syndicate the deal. I have suggested this to AngelList and I hope they will implement it. That would at least address the issue of syndicates not having the startups’ permission to share the deal. But it doesn’t address the issue of due diligence. That can only be solved by you. If you are selective about the deals you invest in and invest only in those where the syndicate lead has done extensive due diligence, you will not only earn much higher returns on your investments, but you may also force more syndicates to start protecting their investors through proper due diligence. You may also want to ask syndicate leads to share their entire track record. We share ours and encourage others to as well.

I understand that a skeptic could read my warning and interpret it as self-promotional. My goal, though, with this letter is not to encourage anyone to invest with Forefront. My goal is to share what I’ve seen unfolding so that you and other angel investors can use this information for your benefit when evaluating any deals you see, from whatever source.

Best,

Phil

Sharing a note on AngelList I received from Phil Nadel at Forefront Venture Partners (affiliated with Barbara Corcoran - although I'm not sure how involved she is). Thought it was worth sharing, given the focus on due diligence. It's a little pitchy at points, but there are good points in here nonetheless for anyone considering whether to invest on AngelList today.

> Hi Andrew,
>
>I was 11 years old when I went skiing for the first time. It was a school trip. I had never taken a ski lesson but didn’t think it looked that difficult. So I rented my skis and followed my friends onto the slopes. Down the slopes I soared, gleeful, until I realized I had a big problem: I didn’t know how to stop. I crashed into barricades at the bottom of the slope and was rushed to the hospital. I still have a scar on my right knee to remind me of this youthful foolishness.
>
>I started helping companies invest in and acquire startups when I was in college. One week after I graduated college, I started my first company--to help SPACs (then called blind pools) acquire target companies. And I have been investing in and advising startups ever since (33+ years).
>
>Just like the skiing accident, I have also been hurt by some of the hundreds of investments I’ve made. I have investment scar tissue. It reminds me every day of the importance of due diligence.
>
>Investing in startups without doing deep due diligence is like skiing down a mountain without having learned the requisite skills. It can feel thrilling, but it’s foolish, it’s dangerous and can often lead to bad outcomes. And scar tissue.
>
>Why am I telling you this? Because I am concerned. Concerned about the startup investing environment, concerned about the lack of due diligence, concerned about the impact of FOMO (fear of missing out) overcoming investors’ good judgment. You are a member of the Forefront Venture Partners syndicate. You are likely also a member of other syndicates on AngelList and perhaps other platforms. I feel it is incumbent on me to alert you to an alarming practice that has cropped up across platforms: syndicates are syndicating deals without doing any due diligence. **In fact, many times, the companies are not even aware that the syndicate has syndicated the deal.** The companies have never spoken to the syndicate lead and have not authorized them to syndicate the deal. The syndicate gets an allocation from another investor in the deal and decides to syndicate it on AngelList. As a result, they have done zero due diligence. And yet you are relying on syndicate leads – and paying them, in the form of carried interest – not just to source deals, but to perform rigorous due diligence. I fear you may not even be aware of the fact that they are often doing no due diligence at all.

>There is a lot of capital in search of startups to invest in — and a rush to deploy it. Investors have FOMO if they miss what seems like a great deal. posts.cooked:
I’m not negating the risks, but IMO if the properties were not entitled and it was just raw dirt, then at that point it’s all speculation and appraisals don’t mean much. Once you have fully approved entitlements, I have not seen a MF entitled property that developers paid under $10k/door in a terrific market, and that’s essentially the appraisal values (between $7k-$12k/door).

This doesn’t negate that if CDP didn’t develop then they would have to find a different Sponsor to sell to and the risks that that entail, but if it truly is a growing “hot” marke, they could fetch those prices.

posts.cooked:
For me after sleeping on it, I just can’t get there on a $100K investment (obviously I’m not in one of the 20 $50K spots). This IMO is an extremely high risk investment. Not just because of development. But so many things need to happen even before development starts on each project of which there are 20+ potential projects. Even aside from that, there’s risk macroeconomic, with Fed unwinding and raising interest rate and this being 5-10 year time fund - and them believing they can sell at 4.6cap in the future. Then there’s the risk that Craig is no young buck, has no partner, and everything that I’ve seen hinges completely on him. Somewhere in the webinar, they spoke about wanting to make sure his first fund comes out good. I somehow think this is his only fund, his last big bang if you will before he retires or gets too old.

On top of that, all the approximations of truths is enough to drive one nuts. How did we all go from believing we are paying $25M for $50M in the 1st webinar, to $13 for $15M? We are all of varying experience, but as a collective I think we are quite smart. Mark asked very specific questions in the 1st webinar and we were all led to believe it was was $25 for $50. This was a miscommunication on the sponsors/Nance’s part. I’m not harboring this point, but given so many things in the works and all the moving parts, if we aren’t currently misled on something now, then we likely will in the future. To be clear, I don’t think it was intentional on sponsor’s part, but they are winging it. Nance said on this webinar “We have LP’s just lining up”. Somehow, since the 1st webinar 9 months ago, that doesn’t seem likely. I don’t doubt they have a lot of possibilities… but lining up? Again, I suspect an approximation of truth.

This is RE. This isn’t some new startup that will disrupt an industry to take a bet on. The “markup” of cost, to appraisal is all paper gains, similar to startups, but does not have the upside of startups. It’s all meaningless unless sold at the appraisal, or taken to completion and then sold - at traditional RE valuations.

I got in line for the $50K, probably behind a dozen of you guys.
I see a couple scenarios:
a) they close on their big investor, and close down this fund month end, and I don’t get in
b) they don’t close on their big investor, and still eager to close down this fund, open $50K slots, and I get an option (not committed at this time)
c) they don’t close on their big investor, and continue fundraising at which point we’ll see if they lock down CLC and the Durham Center parking lot with the city

Any of these scenarios play out about equal in my book, hence I’ll let the scenarios determine my decision.

posts.cooked:
OK, received answers from first batch of questions sent yesterday. Please note in particular that commitments from the 506 Group will be accepted until 2/7 (backdated to 1/31) and that not everyone who asked for a $50K slot has sent in their paperwork. Christy is keeping a waiting list on these.

General
• Please confirm that fund will allow extra week for 506 members to file commitment
Yes, we will give the 506 Group until 2/7/22. PLEASE BE SURE TO HAVE THEM DATE THE PAPERWORK JANUARY 31st IF THEY WILL BE UTILIZING THE EXTRA WEEK.
• Any chance of opening $50K contributions again?
As of now, I have not received all the paperwork for those who reserved a spot for the $50k investment. Please ask members to get their paperwork in ASAP, so that we may open up additional spots if those original 20 do not follow through with their verbal commitment.
• Can the PPM and Operating agreement be posted on the internal 506 CDP site?
We cannot post the docs due to FINRA/SEC rules. Please contact Christy directly for the documents.
• Final raise – is there a set upper limit on how much they will raise before closing fund? Will it go to $30M or$35M? What amount of equity raise are they assuming in their projections?
The target for the fund is $25mm. We do not have an upper limit, but we will accept all Subscription Agreements that we receive from the 506 group by 2/7/22.
• Will management fees only be collected on outstanding capital? The cash flow model showed that management fees will stop once all capital is returned, and that no further fees will be charged to investors in the CDP Fund. Not clear on this after reading the Operating Agreement.
This is correct. The AM Fee will only be paid on unreturned capital.

Debt
• Can you share the terms of the seller financing for Penny Farm?
$4mm at 3.5% over a three (3) year term. This is non-collateralized loan.
• Understand that LoC with First Citizen’s bank is not finalized, but can they share terms as they stand now? Is there any risk of loan being called like they described in the past with Bank of America?
This is still under negotiation. We are unwriting a two (2) year term at a 5% rate. We have also built in two (2) years of interest carry. No, there is no risk that the bank will be able to call the note without an event of default.
• It was stated that this LoC is primarily for Penny Farm. If so, what is the source and terms of Durham II construction loan if different?
That is correct. JLL is currently marketing the debt for The James from multiple sources. I believe the loan assumption have been previously provided

Sources and Uses of Funds document/ Cash Flow Model details (for at least first years) for each project, each one below a separate entry:
• Outflows: land purchases to Craig & Penny Farm, interest payments, real estate taxes, horizontal development costs, lease expenses, etc.
• Inflows: debt transactions, “reimbursement” by the LP, lease payments received, etc.
Let me think about how to do this.

Mission Valley – Understand that many details on this project are still TBD, but as such this is viewed by some as a bigger risk because so much is unknown.
Understood but we hope the cash flow model depicts an attractive investment without Mission Valley. We would not move forward with Mission Valley unless we were able to secure land lease terms that provided the opportunity to achieve acceptable risk adjusted return that were accretive to our investors.
• What the approximate terms are that they think they will have to pay for the land lease, both up-front payments to secure the lease, as well as annual lease payments?
Forthcoming.
• Any details that can be shared on the rent from the current tenants?
Forthcoming.
• Will CDP have to pay the real estate taxes owed in the land lease?
This is still a negotiation point but the lessee typically is responsible for the taxes which is what we have assumed in our underwriting.
• How much less is the land worth in a ground lease to the LP (because the CDP Fund will have to contribute up to 10% equity, and ground lease land is worth less) - meaning, they will have to come up with more cash to make the ground component worth more.
The fund will still contribute the value of the land into the GP position of the vertical construction. The value is typically calculated using a NPV with a discount rate on the amount of the ground lease for that particular phase. This will not require additional equity to participate in the vertical.
• What is the plan on funding all of this cashflow to secure the lease, and then start demolition on part of the site?
The cost for the fund to secure the lease will be minimal. The demolition costs will be part of the vertical construction costs.

This will not require additional equity to participate in the vertical.** 
•	What is the plan on funding all of this cashflow to secure the lease, and then start demolition on part of the site?
**The cost for the fund to secure the lease will be minimal.  The demolition costs will be part of the vertical construction costs.**

posts.cooked:
The following post was reviewed and approved by Jef Baker.

Quoting from the press release above:

Transition of Sortis Fund Management

On December 31, 2021, Sortis sold its fund management business to Sortis, LLC (“Sortis Fund Management”), a private entity owned and operated by former Sortis Holdings managers. The asset purchase was seller financed through a promissory note. With the divestiture, Sortis is positioned to execute its brand platform strategy.

Interpretation:

  • Seller = Sortis Holding, INC (OTC: SOHI)
  • Buyer = Sortis, LLC (“Sortis Fund Management”)
  • “Sortis Fund Management” manages the following:
    • Sortis Income Fund (SIF)
    • Sortis Rescue Fund (SRF)
    • three opportunity zone funds
    • the new Sortis Private REIT Fund
  • This transaction does not change:
    • the people who manage these funds
    • investor terms

SIF IS NOT IMPACTED BY THIS TRANSACTION. The same can be said about the other funds except for SRF.

The section of the press release titled “Strategic Acquisitions” does impact the Rescue Fund, as the assets acquired were within this fund.

Comments from Jef Baker:

Sortis Fund Manager, LLC, the manager of the various Funds related to Sortis, recently registered with the SEC. Sortis Fund Manager was owned by Sortis Holdings, Inc. and on 1/1/22 is now owned by Sortis, LLC. The senior management of Sortis Holdings, Inc. (Jef Baker, Paul Brenneke, Sam Ross and Michael Sander) are the partners of Sortis, LLC (i.e., the exact management overseeing the various Funds continue to oversee the Funds). The Fund management business is not consistent with the forward looking activities of Sortis Holdings, Inc, which include continuing to acquire and oversee a portfolio of operating business in the hospitality, food & beverage (including coffee), and health and wellness space. A management team to operate that platform has been accumulated within Sortis Holdings over the last year to accommodate the shift. Also, it is not common to have a public company (Sortis Holdings, Inc.) owning a fund management business, where the management are employees. Rather a traditional structure is to have the fund management business operated as a partnership. In addition, 100% of the administrative employees that work on the Fund Management businesses are still fulfilling their roles, but now as employees of Sortis, LLC vs. Sortis Holdings. Inc.

    • Let’s try to reserve judgment until we have heard the whole story.

This is the first time a deal went into a CS fund that was not offered on platform for direct investment. Many of the group’s most popular sponsors were on a crowd platform at one point (eg. MLG, ApexOne). Sponsor quality imo has generally increased with time, not decreased. I suppose we don’t know for sure if they picked a dud or not for their fund, but I’m guessing they tried to cherry pick a winner to help market their fund.

I wouldn’t be surprised if they expand offerings to include offerings that don’t require AI status (similar to fundirse) so they can expand their investor base, but frankly I’ve seen them offer more QP only investments over the year. So I see it all as expansion rather than pívot. Time will tell.

posts.cooked:
I was recently referred by a very well reputed source in the industry to hard money lender (OCG Properties) similar to Sortis. After reaching out to them, i learned that they are offering 7% returns and they are unlevered. I was not interested and when pressed as to what alternative options I had, i informed them that i was earning 10.3% with Sortis for a similar product. Below was his response, and i think it was worth sharing with the group:

I don’t understand how they are making any money. If they have a fund and its 90% invested and they are lending at 12% then they are netting 10.8% so they would be making a 0.5% spread which is crazy low. If they have a fund paying you 10.3% unleveraged, what are they lending at and what types of deals are they invested in? Also why would they use investor money at 10.3%? There are insurance companies and banks that I sell to at 7% that literally buy all debt from me where I can make my interest rate spread profit with zero risk. I am lending out at 10% - 12% interest rates to my borrowers which is the max you can really get with the competition out there unless you are doing high LTV or no money down type deals or land deals, etc. I am curious to see what they actually invest in to understand the risk profile.

Thanks for the info, always interested in understanding, I just do not need to pay more because if I want I can sell all of my paper to those banks and insurance companies instead of raising more money in my fund (that I look at as me being at risk for because I would take a bullet for my investors money and treat it like my own).

I wanted to see if anyone had the same thoughts/concerns because it does appear that they are lending at 12%?

Thanks

posts.cooked:
The trick in HML is to have very low overhead, a large % of Cap Table in Equity, and local presence in your physical market. In addition you must have the capability to take over any defaulted project and make more money on the completion of the project than the Company would made if the loan performed.

In a private fund that I am a member of we earn between 12% and 16% annualized depending on cash drag in any one quarter.

I find the comment from that gentleman to be valid for his experience, because he probably has never been on the street really making loans rather than pushing paper.

But I have also been in the business for over 15 years.

Ralph

posts.cooked:
Are you sure they are similar? Socotra for instance is a HML on mostly commercial but largely stabilized or cash flowing assets and they net investors about 8%. SIF is much higher risk in commercial bridge loans, which most traditional lenders won’t touch. Arixa was doing HML on SFR mostly and netting investors 7%, and they decided to pivot more into commercial, mainly multifamily. Looking at OCG’s website, they mainly deal with residential and MF, which is probably the crux of the rate difference.

If the underlying product is not considered, then of course one would just go with the highest yield.

posts.cooked:
I agree with @DanielChang and @RalphBowlin 's comments and have two things to add.

In his numbers, Mr. OCG:

  1. Ignores the income from loan fees, which can be significant in a fund whose loans average 8-months (12-month terms with many early payoffs). Guessing here, but some funds don’t share these fees with investors and this may explain why it was ignored.

  2. Overestimates the cash drag at “90% invested”. SIF runs close to 100% as I understand.

posts.cooked:
SCIRE Fund III Investor,

Good afternoon! We are excited to announce that SCIRE Fund III just closed on a $7,000,000 portfolio spanning 3 Mobile Home Communities (“MHC”) in Rhinelander, Wisconsin. The portfolio includes one-hundred seventy-one (171) total home-sites and the assets are currently 97.1% occupied. The acquisition target was sourced by one of our contacts in the industry and we were able to put the asset under contract without competition.

SCIRE Fund III purchased the asset utilizing fixed-rate, low-interest debt provided by Freddie Mac at 3.23% with $5,365,000 in proceeds to include several years of Interest Only payments. Seneca called the capital for this transaction in December 2021 (to include the asset acquisition in Omaha) so there is no action required by our Fund III investors.

Mobile Home lot rents at the assets average $350 per month and all of the Communities are serviced by City water and sewer. Less than twenty (20) lots have submeters installed and the utility expenses are not currently billed back to the tenants so there is significant upside regarding sub-metering directly to the tenants. Moreover, SCIRE Fund III is now the largest owner of MHC’s in the micro-market with plans to set the market benchmark for affordable rents.

The assets all reside across the street from each other in Oneida County, where Rhinelander is the County Seat and the regional hub (to include the Upper Peninsula of MI) for all services, retail outlets and industry. In 2019, Oneida County had a population of 36k with a media age of 51.3 and a median household income of $56,852. Between 2018 and 2019, the median household income grew from $54,198 to $56,852 - a 4.9% increase. With the COVID pandemic, thousands of new residents are flocking to the area due to the unmatched recreational amenities nearby. The median home cost in Oneida County is $205,200. Home appreciation the last 10 years has been 22.6%.

Wisconsin has the highest percentage of workforce directly involved in manufacturing nationwide which leads to a stable, predictable tenant base with access to high paying, technical jobs. There are significant employers in the area which drove the population and job growth for the residents.

Please see our detailed business plan attached. Thank you for your continued support and have a wonderful weekend.
My best,
Rhett

Rhett Trees
Founder and CEO
Seneca Capital Partners

posts.cooked:
Thanks Saul,

You bring up some great points. I think for someone wanting a simple portfolio, this makes perfect sense. I do feel blessed by all the opportunities in the USA. Hopefully, the USA is always a great place to invest.

As I grow and have access to great international investments, I would like to still be financially “okay” if my USA investments were to struggle due to many possibilities (geopolitical conflict, etc.).

I agree that international diversification, especially outside of traditional public markets, adds another layer of risk and complexity. This is a strategy and portfolio I’d hope to grow into over time.

Thanks for your response. I’ll focus less on trying to profit from the currency exchange.

activity.topic_name: I Bonds - Series I Savings Bonds - TreasuryDirect

posts.cooked:
Here’s one more way to buy more ibonds. Buy as a gift and deliver in the future. The initial gift buying does not count count toward the buyer’s limit, but will count to the recipient’s annual limit when delivered to the recipient. So, say, you buy $10k as a gift to be gifted next year to your spouse. Your spouse do the same. Or gift to your kids, business and trusts?

“It also works to a limited extent if you think the high interest rates on I Bonds are only temporary. You can buy a gift for your spouse and hold it in your gift box. Have your spouse do the same for you. Wait until interest rates drop and the two of you don’t buy I Bonds anymore. Then you can deliver the gift to each other. The older gift bonds earned the high interest rates in the years past and they have aged enough for immediate cashout. Because there’s a limit in how much you can deliver to the same person each year, don’t go overboard with this. If you hold $100,000 in the gift box and the interest rates are no longer competitive, those bonds will be in limbo for a long time while earning uncompetitive interest rates.”

The Finance Buff – 27 Dec 21

Buy I Bonds as a Gift: What Works and What Doesn't

I Bonds bought as a gift counts toward the recipient's purchase limit. Buying as gift for your spouse works when the high interest rates are only temporary.

Est. reading time: 7 minutes

First, we received a due diligence extension from the seller which now extends through January 22 which moves the expected close date to the end of February. As we have additional time to complete our diligence, we are able to extend our subscription period to February 18, 2022. As a reminder, we are seeking to raise approximately $56 million in equity to complete this transaction and have received approximately $35 million in soft commitments to date. We remain confident in our ability to raise the required equity and are working with our own networks as well as a few select advisors in an effort to raise the remaining funds. We are very excited about this opportunity and look forward to closing this transaction! As always, thank you for your continued support.

posts.cooked:
Good news. Signed a new lease and distribution getting bumped to 10%. I’m happy with this so far even if the sponsor communication has been a bit choppy

Deerfield Corporate Park continues to be a strong performer in the Southeast office space sector. The rent roll of the asset remains strong, anchored by major tenants such as Cell Sciences and Toshiba Solutions. Our leasing activity for 2022 looks bright: we have a new signed lease with Omnitron Electronics for 1,800 square feet and $180,000 of capital improvements planned, mainly related to building painting to give the asset a nice facelift. Given the increased demand for single story, private entrance office space in the Southeast market, any future vacancies should be easily re-leasable, keeping the asset’s occupancy on target with the original offering memorandum.

The asset has met all expectation and performed well since acquisition, finishing 2021 with an occupancy rate of 90% and a collection rate for the year of 100%. Due to the performance of the asset, we would like to remind the partners and highlight that the accrued distributions that were on hold in 2020 due to COVID-19 uncertainty were fully repaid during 2021.

At this time, we are pleased to announce additional good news. After reviewing the asset’s 2022 budget, the rosy economic outlook for this market and future expected performance of the project, we believe it is prudent to increase the distributions to 10% annum based on each partner’s original capital basis. The increased distributions will start with the January 2022 distributions, which will be paid in February as they are paid in arrears.

We are pleased with the performance of the asset thus far and continue to be excited about the future prospects of the business center and the continued growth of the Southeast market. We will be sending a detailed quarterly report next month. However, should you have any questions in the meantime, please feel free to reach out to us at investor@denholtz.com. We are here to help!

> 
> The asset has met all expectation and performed well since acquisition, finishing 2021 with an occupancy rate of 90% and a collection rate for the year of 100%. Due to the performance of the asset, we would like to remind the partners and highlight that the accrued distributions that were on hold in 2020 due to COVID-19 uncertainty were fully repaid during 2021.
> 
> At this time, we are pleased to announce additional good news. After reviewing the asset's 2022 budget, the rosy economic outlook for this market and future expected performance of the project, we believe it is prudent to increase the distributions to 10% annum based on each partner's original capital basis. The increased distributions will start with the January 2022 distributions, which will be paid in February as they are paid in arrears.
> 
> We are pleased with the performance of the asset thus far and continue to be excited about the future prospects of the business center and the continued growth of the Southeast market. We will be sending a detailed quarterly report next month. However, should you have any questions in the meantime, please feel free to reach out to us at [investor@denholtz.com](mailto:investor@denholtz.com). We are here to help!
